title: If you could see your future and change it, would you? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not possible. If I see my own future, then nothing I do could change it, otherwise I would not end up being that same person that was shown to my own past self at that moment. Or, maybe this is merely an example of somebody who very, very closely resembles what a future me might look like, in which case I can rest assured that it isn’t me, and so what I’m seeing isn’t my future. Let’s say CERN (Conseil Européen pour la Recherche Nucléaire, or the European Council for Nuclear Research) already invented a time machine back in 1975. I end up working for CERN, and in 2016 gain access to the time machine, and use it to show my 1975 self what I have become today. Forty-one years of a series of coincidences and intertwined events led me to the very special place where I had access to a time machine, and due to the butterfly effect, certainly any tiny change during that 41 years could have led to any number of radically different outcomes, nearly all of which involve me not hijacking that time machine. So, for that to still be “me” that’s using that time machine (and I assure you it truly is me, the real me, not one of CERN’s shapeshifters), and for that to be the real “past me” that’s seeing it, every single infinitesimal fraction of a second that the “past me” experiences between that very instant in 1975 and when I used the time machine in 2016 must be exactly the same. It would literally be impossible to do anything any differently. Now, let’s say I use this opportunity to have the past me go track down an old IBM 5100 workstation which still has a tape in it with the schematics for a time machine that I invented during my time at CERN. In 2016, this oversized pocket calculator has long turned to dust in a landfilll, but in 1975 it’s cutting-edge tech, and in perfect condition, save for the pizza grease on the keys. The 1975 me finds it, builds the device described on that tape, and so invents time travel. But…who actually wrote those design schematics? It was me, right? But where did the actual information come from? If it was the future me that gave them to the past me, at what point did I actually write those schematics? It’s as if those plans just materialized out of nothing, that is, there’s an effect that never once had a cause. Backwards time travel may not be allowed by the laws of Nature. Rather than speculate about what you could’ve done better, what you should’ve done, focus on what you can do right now, today, to improve. It’s pointless to cry over the past. The present is where we all live, where we’ve always lived, and where we will continue to live.
